message: What do you guys think would be a good use for this group, to fit well into the Haskell ecosystem?

I seem to think it fits right in between IRC and Mailing Lists. My hope, I suppose, would be for longer term discussions than IRC would allow (though still with a technical focus like an IRC conversation might have), but perhaps not deemed appropriate enough for a mailing list (whatever would qualify something as that). Right now, the group isn't that active, and I'd love to see that change.

@Miikka Sure, and so the one obvious appeal is that it's more accessible, but to the Haskell audience, it's not like IRC isn't. I'd say the one benefit of Convore's IRC-style over IRC itself is the ability to easily persist conversations–great for longer term discussions.
Maybe I'm a pessimist, but to me Convore seems to be pretty much IRC gone Web 2.0 (or maybe we're at 3.0 already?)
Yeah. I haven't used Convore much yet, so I don't know how it turns out in practice. Obviously it's a bit of a chicken-or-egg problem.
I think Convore is like IRC but with support (meaning they keep adding features to the protocol), I think if it becomes as successful as IRC, we can expect more activity in this group.
IRC isn't really accessible for me. I'm most likely to be using Haskell at work, and IRC is blocked. Convore isn't (although now I've said that, it probably will be soon).
I've gone off the idea of mailing lists as I just end up with email overload.
@atomicules same here. I end up only reading every other haskell-cafe digest - Haskell's really popular now.
@atomicules I've fallen into the same problem–especially with Gmail's filters, where I can just tuck major mailing lists off into their own label and never really look at them due to time.
(I shouldn't have said anything. Convore now blocked along with IRC)
@atomicules We need to get @leah over here to implement the anti-star, thumbs down, or something, so I can show my dislike of that :(
